page.title: 04Smarden Land Use 2
page.content: In this area farm sizes vary but they are still family enterprises, using very little outside help except for tractor drivers and cowmen. There have been changes in the past few years, pigs and poultry have almost entirely gone and pastureland is now mainly used by sheep. The local Romney breed predominate but the prolific north country crosses are gaining favour. They tend to be housed during the worst of the winter weather. Lights dotted about the countryside at night show where lambing is in progress. Dairy cow numbers remain the same, there are a few small herds, mainly Friesian, kept in modern conditions and housed for nearly 6 months of the year. Milk is sent to the big dairies; there are a few beef cattle, the by-product of the dairy industry.
